WHHS Students Place in National Competition

More than 6,000 students are participating in the 2020 National Speech and Debate Association’s National Tournament this weekend. Students are debating ideas, voicing their views, and sharing their stories. White House High School juniors Rebekah Langford and Madison Freeman both advanced to the octofinals with Langford moving onto semi-finals, then finals. Freeman finished in the top 30 for Expository and in the top 60 for Prompt speaking. Langford finished in the top 60 in Prose and top 12 for Storytelling.

The pair previously qualified for the tournament to be held in Albuquerque, New Mexico. Due to COVID-19 the national tournament was moved to an online platform. Both Freeman and Langford were named 2020 Academic All-Americans by the National Speech and Debate Association (NSDA) back in May. There are approximately 200,000 NSDA members, and only the top two percent are chosen to receive this prestigious award. They are coached by Emily Higdon. Congratulations ladies! #SumnerAchieves #SumnerCountyStrong

The goal is to prepare our students so that they are able to present themselves exceptionally well for opportunities today as well as those that will come in the future.

The Amazing Shake National Competition is open to any student in the 5th-8th grade during the 2020-2021 school year.

Two Sumner County High School Students can now add Songwriter to their resume! Portland High School's Honors English IV class, taught by Charlie McCoin, participated in the Words and Music Program at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum. The program teaches the fundamentals of songwriting using ELA standards. Students wrote the lyrics, and professional songwriters turned their lyrics into songs.

The Country Music Hall of Fame then hosted a Words and Music night showcasing the best of the students' songs from the year. They choose a handful of songs written as a part of the program to be performed. More than 5,000 songs were written as a part of this program, and our very own Portland High School Seniors, Samantha Alda Katherine and Addison Dorris were chosen to be apart of the show.

Typically, this night would be an opportunity for the songwriters, students, and music industry professionals to meet, greet, and hear the music at the Hall of Fame. Due to COVID-19, this year will be a virtual concert. Congratulations to Samantha and Addison! #SumnerAchieves #SumnerCountyStrong

Sumner County Schools Hosts Education Leaders

Sumner County Schools hosted around 175 educational leaders from around the region including National Literacy expert and author Natalie Wexler.

Assistant Director of Instruction, Scott Langford, kicked the meeting off with the importance of curriculum and how it plays a key role in developing, implementing, assessing, modifying and shaping a school.

Before introducing The Knowledge Gap author, Supervisor of Teaching and Learning, Christy Wall, spoke about the importance of literacy and how schools can promote early reading and writing skills.

Sumner County Administrators, Instructional Coordinators, Lead Educators, Teachers, Board Members and politicians listened as Natalie Wexler spoke about knowledge-focused schools. She discussed how educators that consistently incorporate curriculum and material to broaden students' knowledge and vocabulary will guide students towards academic success, hence closing The Knowledge Gap.

Thank you to Welch College for letting us host on their campus.

The competitive STEM classroom grant program, operated in partnership with Battelle Education, received grant requests from six states across TVA’s service territory. 93 schools were awarded with a grant and two of them are Sumner County Schools!

“This is the second year we offered this program to the entire Valley and we saw a major increase in grant applications this year,” said Community Engagement Senior Program Manager Rachel Crickmar. “There is a demand in the Valley for workforce development through STEM education and I am proud of the way TVA and our retirees are responding to that demand.”

Congratulations teachers and students! We can’t wait to see how STEM grows in your school.

What better way to test Indian Lake Elementary’s parachutes than by real Paratroopers! Army Reserve members are dropping student made parachutes from the roof of the school! Students have been working with the paratrooper’s all day and learning about aerodynamics and fluid flow concepts that are used to design planes, ships, and of course parachutes! Accounting for drag is an important aspect of these designs, students have been redesigning the shape and materials used to get better results. In each box attached to the parachute is an egg. The goal was to get the egg safely to the ground and we had several successful missions today!

Special thanks to our Army members! We are grateful for everything you do! THANK YOU!
